loans.name: Sa'ade

texts.en: Sa'ade remembers not being able to feed her family  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before she became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Sa'ade, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Sa'ade  is ambitious and is aiming to reap up to 35 bags per hectare this season. “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community” expressed Sa'ade. With this loan, Sa'ade is well on her way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Shameem

texts.en:
Shameem is a 43-year-old married woman. She is a mother of six children and lives in a joint family system.

Shameem and her husband have been running a business of buying and selling wood for the past ten years. Over time, the business has grown, and now they have a strong customer-base. Shameem plays a vital role in managing the business. Her husband purchases wood from the market at lower rates and she sells it from her home at a reasonable price. 

She has requested a loan of 45,000 PKR to expand her business. With the loan amount she intends to purchase more good quality wood at lower prices, for resale. She is confident and has good market knowledge to expand her business. She dreams of providing good food and health to her family members, through all her hard work in her business. She is in her 8th loan cycle.

loans.use: to purchase more good quality wood at lower prices, for resale.

loans.name: Salina

texts.en:
HELLO! Meet Salina who is 59 years old, and is very hardworking, honest and humble. She hails from Eldoret, Kenya - an area that is blessed with elite and world renowned runners, and also the best weather patterns that favor farming activities. Salina is a proud mother of seven children that she really loves and adores and will do anything in her power to always give them the best. Salina has been farming for the past 29 years and through these years she has always provided them with all the basic needs that they require.

Salina practices mixed farming - that is crop and animal farming, and through these two she has been able to support her family, but she still faces challenges, which is why she wants to diversify and start poultry farming so that she can make ends meet. She is seeking a loan to buy poultry and she believes that through the increased income she will be able to comfortably take care of her family and assure her grandchildren of a secure future.

Salina has experienced difficulties in acquiring funds to start her poultry business but she now feels relieved knowing that Juhudi Kilimo is partnering with Kiva and other lenders to support aspiring women like her to be economically empowered and be able to realize their dreams. Because of the many years that Salina has had in farming she has learned the culture of saving and being honest with money, and she hopes through the loan she will be able to save more and repay the loan on time.

She believes that the loan will assist her to improve her living conditions and secure the future of her grandchildren.

loans.use: to buy poultry.

loans.name: Batchimeg

texts.en:
Batchimeg, aged 35, lives with her husband and two children in Darkhan, the second largest city of Mongolia. She has been running a beauty salon since 2002 and she rents out four seats. Her husband also runs his own business selling clothes. Their two children both go to school. They live in a house on a plot of land and grow vegetables for domestic use. 

Batchimeg is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to dig a well on her land to provide the family's water needs. By having a well dug, she will be able to irrigate vegetables as well as getting water for free instead of buying it from a water outlet.

loans.use: to dig a well to provide for the family's water needs and to irrigate their vegetables

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
HELLO LENDERS! Meet Jane - a 45-year-old mother who is very humble, honest and one of the most hardworking women on this planet earth. She hails from Eldoret - an area that is home to the best athletes in Kenya and also known as the “city of champions”.

Jane is a mother of five children that she really adores and cherishes and will always do anything in her power to fully support. She has been farming for the past 19 years, and through those years she has been able to gather so much experience and all the farming techniques are in her fingertips. Eldoret is an area with a large population and has a ready market for poultry products. That is why Jane decided to venture into poultry farming. Also, there is underutilized space in Jane’s farm. Through the loan, Jane will comfortably take care of her family and be able to assure her family of a bright future.

For women like Jane, having access to financial resources through Juhudi Kilimo and Kiva will increase their productivity and impact their future.
Because of the ready market available, the financial benefits Jane will reap are almost immediate and hence repaying the loan will never be a problem.

loans.use: to buy poultry.

loans.name: Sahib

texts.en:
Sahib is a 58-year-old married woman and a mother of four children. Her husband’s daily wage is not enough to support her family. Therefore, a few years ago, she decided to support her family in order to provide them with a better and secure future. She started the business of retail shopkeeping with the help of her husband. Now she has a reputable shop in her community. Her customers are satisfied and respect her due to her honesty in business. 

She is in her fifth loan cycle with Kashf foundation and has shown good credit behavior. Now, she has requested a loan of 40, 000 PKR to purchase stock of rice, grains, spices, biscuits, beverages etc. She wants to use the profits from the business to fulfill her family’s needs.

loans.use: to purchase stock of rice, grains, spices, biscuits, beverages etc.

loans.name: Izolda

texts.en:
Izolda is 67 years old. She lives in Lagodekhi district, Kakheti region, East Georgia. She is involved in agricultural activities. In particular, Izolda owns a plot of agricultural land where different kinds of vegetables are grown. She is a very hard-working woman and does her best to ensure a good harvest. 

Izolda has requested a loan to purchase a cow. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables her to receive a loan of 1,500 GEL. With the received credit, she will purchase a cow and start producing cheese. She already has a shed for the cow in her yard. Izolda will increase her income by selling cheese and will be able to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase a cow to start producing cheese to sell

loans.name: Gul Naz

texts.en:
Gul Naz has successfully built her general store business with the support of Kashf Foundation and Kiva. She has attained a good number of customers and makes a good amount of income to contribute in the family income. 

Previously, with the help of Kiva, she was able to expand her business. Now she is in her seventh loan cycle and has applied a loan of 40,000 PKR to buy stock of grocery items such as grains, sugar, oil and biscuits. This will enable her to meet the demands of her customers on time.

loans.use: to buy stock of grocery items such as grains, sugar, oil and biscuits.

loans.name: Lusine

texts.en:
This nice and very charming lady’s name is Lusine and she happily lives with her family in Vanadzor in Lori region. She is married and has a seven-year-old daughter. Lusine has a higher pedagogical education and now works at a school as a teacher of English Language. She is a very kind, clever and patient teacher whom her pupils like and respect very much. Lusine is very happy to mention that every pupil is very well prepared for her lesson: she works with great enthusiasm and pleasure to give them as much knowledge as possible. Lusine also has a group of pupils to whom she gives private courses in English Language and prepares them for entrance examinations. 

Lusine very much wants to separate the room that she uses for her private courses so it is more comfortable for her pupils and more useful for the teaching process. This loan will help her to furnish that room: to buy chairs, bookshelves and also some professional literature.

loans.use: to buy chairs, bookshelves and some professional literature for the room used for private courses

loans.name: Narine

texts.en:
Narine lives in the village Varser in the Gegharkunik region. She has a nice, cute farm, the income of which helps to sustain her peasant family’s humble needs. Narine runs her farm with her beloved husband who is unemployed now. 

On her farm, Narine breeds three cows, two calves, a bull, five piglets and ten chickens. From her farm, Narine sells dairy-products that she has made, cheese, butter, macun (national dairy-product), milk, and also meat and eggs. She says she likes her village life and farming, and she hopes that her children will stay in their native village and develop her farm and enlarge the farm in the future.
 
Narine has two sons; the elder son works at the butcher shop and the younger son is going to enter the institute.

Narine has requested this loan in order to buy a calf, and as she says, to start the enlargement of her farm little by little.

loans.use: to buy a calf.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en: Halima is a Babban Gona farmer from Chiroma. Halima expressed that she is driven by one goal; to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Halima to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, she finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Halima can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Halima, is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 30 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Halima will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what she plans to do with her income from this season, she said: “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland”. With this loan, Halima will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Esther joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her  children: . Esther is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Esther will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, she would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Esther can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how she plans to spend the income she will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, she said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Esther is not thinking about this year alone; she expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Ya'u

texts.en: Ya'u remembers not being able to pay school fees during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona member. Now, Ya'u, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Ya'u is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community”, expressed Ya’u. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Stellah

texts.en:
Stellah is 33 years old and is married to Jacob. They are blessed with two children aged 11 and 7 years old .Stellah has been running a salon for the last seven years and earns a monthly income of KES 20, 000.
	 
Stellah has applied for her second loan of 15,000 KES from VisionFund Kenya, and intends to use the loan to buy more stock of cosmetics and purchase more blow dryers for use in the salon.                                                                                           

She will use the profits to cater for the family's basic needs. She hopes to grow her business and be financially stable.

loans.use: to buy more stock of cosmetics and purchase more blow  dryers.

loans.name: Lawrence

texts.en:
WONDERFUL KIVA LENDERS! Meet Lawrence - a 31-year-old enterprising, humble and hardworking farmer from Eldoret, Kenya, an area known because it has produced the best athletes in the world and also it’s referred to as the “home of champions”. 

Lawrence is a father of two lovely children that he really loves and adores and will do anything within his powers to comfortably take care of. Lawrence has been practicing farming for the last seven years and through farming he has been able to earn a decent and honest income and comfortably provide the basic needs for his family.

Lawrence practices mixed farming - that is crop and dairy farming, and through these two farming activities he always puts food on the table for his family. Although Lawrence has been making profits through selling vegetables and milk to the nearby markets and neighbors, not everything has been easy for this humble and industrious man. He has been facing a challenge of transporting his produce to the market and the timely delivery of products. Lawrence sells perishable products such as milk and vegetables and he does not have proper storage facilities, therefore he needs to make sure that they reach the market on time. Because of poor feeder roads and the transport network in his area, he has faced a challenge, that is why he is seeking a loan to buy a motorbike that will help him in transporting his products to the market.

Through the loan, Lawrence will be able to timely deliver his products, and he will earn more profits because he will be selling his products at a high cost because they are still fresh.

Lawrence's dream is to be able to secure the future of his two children and to be able to improve his living conditions. Through improved profits Lawrence is sure that his dream will be achieved, and he will also have a positive impact in his society through creating employment because he intends to employ someone to be riding the motorbike. Lawrence is waiting for your kindness so that he can realize his dream.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike to transport his products to market.

loans.name: Shurenchimeg

texts.en:
Shurenchimeg, aged 26, lives with her husband, daughter, son and mother in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live in a traditional Mongolian ger (a portable felt dwelling) on a plot of land. Shurenchimeg has been working as a nurse at a private hospital since December 2013. Her husband is an interior designer and works at a building company. Their daughter is five years old and goes to kindergarten, and their two-year-old son stays at home with his grandmother. 

Shurenchimeg is requesting a loan of 3,300,000 MNT to buy fibreglass and foam for the renovation of her family's ger. After the renovation, her family will live in a comfortable and warm place where less coal will need to be burned for heating and, thus, less pollutants will be released into the air.

loans.use: to buy fibreglass and foam for the renovation of her family's ger

loans.name: Sarantsetseg

texts.en:
Sarantsetseg is 33 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Darkhan, the second largest city of Mongolia. She has recently started work as an accountant at a private company which specializes in restoring damaged land. Her husband transports coal between districts. Their two sons are in the ninth and third grade classes at school. 

The house her family lives in has been deteriorating over the years and it needs some repair. She is requesting a loan of 4,000,000 MNT to buy building materials such as bricks, cement, fiberglass and foam for house renovations. She hopes that her family will live in a comfortable and warm place where less coal is burned for heating, and then less pollutants are released into air.

loans.use: to buy building materials in order to renovate her house for energy efficiency and clean air.

loans.name: Noé De Jesés

texts.es:
Noé de 54 años de edad, es jornalero, estudió hasta tercer grado, él deseaba seguir estudiando pero no tuvo el apoyo de sus padres, ya que eran de muy bajos recursos economicos, creció y tuvo la necesidad de hacer su hogar, su compañera de vida es ama de casa, han procreado 4 hijos, todos están estudiando y dependen economicamente de él.

 Noé se dedica a la agricultura desde muy pequeño, tambien trabaja como corralero en una en su localidad, conoce muy bien ambos trabajos y son su fuente de ingresos para él y su familia.

Con el préstamo cancelará un saldo pendiente del préstamo anterior y comprará fertilizantes para el cultivo de maíz.

El sueño de Noé es preparar académicamente a sus hijos, mejorar y ampliar la vivienda.
texts.en:
Noé is a 54-year-old day-labourer. He was schooled up to third grade and wanted to carry on, but did not have the support of his parents as they were really badly off economically. He grew up and had to make a home for himself. His life partner is a housewife, and they have 4 children together. The children all go to school and are dependent on him financially. He has worked in agriculture since he was very small. He also works as a farm-hand on a nearby farm. He knows both jobs really well and they are the source of income for him and his family.

Noé will pay off the balance on his previous loan and will buy fertilisers for his maize crop. His dream is to give his children an education and to improve and extend their house.

loans.use: to clear the balance on a previous loan and to buy fertilisers for his crops.

loans.name: Vitore

texts.en:
Vitore wanted to add some more items to the store; so far she has been selling only clothing, however she believes that by adding more to the inventory, she will be more competitive in the local market. Some items that she wanted to add are perfumes, purses and other accessories.
 
Vitore is very appreciative to you all who have helped her financially in the past and is sending wishes for a good rest of the summer.

loans.use: to add more inventory items such as perfumes, purses and other accessories to her clothing store.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a 56-year-old married lady and she has been blessed with four children who are now adults. She has been practicing both crop and animal farming for the last 28 years and this has been able to cater for her family's needs as well as her own.

She has applied for her first loan with us after she joined Visionfund Kenya and she plans to use this amount to buy two pigs for rearing and future resale. She hopes this will increase the income and she plans to use the amount to repay her loan.

In the future, she hope to be able to have enough for her daily bread.

loans.use: to purchase two pigs.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Hello Kiva lenders! Meet Mercy, a 25-year-old caring, honest and very hard-working mother of one child, who hails from Eldoret, the area of Kenya that is home to all the elite runners in long-distance races. Mercy is a very hard-working farmer who is easy to get along with. She has been practising farming for the past four years during which she has never looked back because she has been making good profits and taking great strides in terms of farming.
 
Mercy practises mixed farming, that is, crop and dairy farming and through these ventures she has been able to earn a decent and honest income. She is  an early riser who wakes up very early to go to her farm because farming is the only way that she can earn a living.

Mercy has identified space on her farm that she wants to fully utilise through dairy farming. This is why she is kindly requesting a loan to buy a dairy cow. Eldoret is an area that has a high population and a high demand for milk: Mercy, being an enterprising person, wants to take full advantage of that and be able to earn extra income. She hopes that the extra income that she earns through this loan will allow her to change her standard of living and expand her milk-selling business.

Through the accumulated profits, Mercy is planning that she will be able to open a very large milk-selling business in the nearby shopping centre and also to package milk ready for selling. She wants to be economically empowered but, being a woman, she knows that accessing funds is challenging. However, knowing that there are partners such as Juhudi Kilimo and Kiva, she feels relieved and knows that all her dreams will be achieved and she will be able to provide a secure future  for her child and also improve her family's living conditions. Mercy patiently awaits your kindness.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to build a new stable since the old one was primitive and fell on the ground.

loans.name: Albina

texts.en: Albina wants to install energy efficient doors and windows and make some little repairs to her family home. Her family lives in a building that was built under the communist era, and since then there has been no repairs. She is requesting your help to make it happen and stays positive that you would lend to her again.

loans.use: to make home improvements by installing energy efficient doors and windows.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase and run two Fresh Life toilets.

loans.name: Johnson

texts.en:
Johnson is a 30-year-old single man. He supports his parents and siblings back home. Johnson runs a retail shop but he also has a farm where he does crop farming and has a few animals. From these businesses he is able to make a monthly profit of KES 30,000 which he is happy wit,h as it caters for his needs.

He has applied for his second loan which he hopes to use to add more stock in his retail shop, such as flour, sweets, soaps, etc., as these are currently running low in his shop. He hopes to us the anticipated profits to repay his loan and expand his business.

In the future he would like to be very successful in his business as well as be able to provide for his family.

loans.use: to add more stock to his retail shop.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 45 years old and is married to Lucy. They are blessed with three children aged 22, 18 and 11 years. Daniel has been running a photo studio for the last 20 years and earns a monthly income of KES 35,000.
	 
He has applied for his second loan of 15,000 KES from VisionFund Kenya and intends to use the loan to buy one good quality digital camera for better and clear photos.                                                                                           

Daniel will use the profits to provide for the family's basic needs. He hopes to grow his business and open a bigger studio.

loans.use: to buy one good quality digital camera for better and clear photos.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is a 30-year-old divorced woman and is blessed with two children. She has been running a fruit and vegetable stall for a period of one year, earning an income of KES 8,000 at the end of every month.

Mercy is now servicing her second loan of KES 15,000 with VisionFund Kenya, and intends to add more stock of vegetables, pineapples, oranges and mangoes to sell to her customers on a daily basis.  

Mercy plans to use the anticipated income to educate her children and be able to further their education to higher levels and hopes to become a successful businesswoman with a bright future.

loans.use: to buy vegetables, pineapples, oranges and mangoes to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Johnbosco

texts.en:
Johnbosco is 41 years old, married, and blessed with three children. He has been crop and animal farming for the last four years, and from these he is able to make a monthly profit of KES 35,000.

He has requested his fourth loan from Visionfund Kenya which he plans to use to buy animal feed and fertilizers for his farm. He hopes to make good profits so that he can save this towards the education of his children.

In the future he would like to become a large scale farmer and educate his children to the highest level possible.

loans.use: to buy feed for livestock and fertilizers for his farm.

loans.name: Shazia

texts.en:
Shazia, a 32-year-old lady, has three children. She has been providing sewing services in her locality for five years. She sews for the people of her community and uses the income to support her entire family. 

Shazia is in her third loan cycle. She has now requested a loan of 40,000 PKR which she intends to use to buy a new sewing machine, needles, thimbles, fabric marking pens, etc. This will help her to create a way to increase her revenue, so she may able to generate a healthier source of income. 

Shazia is thankful to Kashf Foundation for the loan and is hopeful that it will help her to secure more customers.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine, needles, thimbles, fabric marking pens, etc.

loans.name: Angjelina

texts.en:
Angjelina started to build a fence around her agricultural land, but she could not finish it due to a lack of money. The land is open and animals get in there and destroy her plants; sometimes people too pick her ripe fruit. 

Angjelina is a 49-year-old villager and a married mother of two children, aged 21 and 17 who continue to go to schools respectively. For years now she has been doing agricultural / livestock work. Currently she has 2 sows, 70 chickens and 1 cow; she sell piglets, eggs, hens & chickens and also raw milk. Angjelina also plants seasonal veggies, grains and crops and has grapevines.
 
She lives in northern Albania. Before she relocated to this new location, she and her family lived in a far northern village, almost in the Alps where the life was very difficult, since the roads were not paved and there was no electricity.

loans.use: to build a fence around her agricultural land.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a 30-year-old married woman and is blessed with two children aged 10 and 7. She has been running a photography studio business for the last four years. From this business she is able to make a monthly profit of 20,000 KES, which when added to her husband's income, is able to cater for their family's needs.

She just joined Visionfund after being introduced by one of our credit officers. Her first loan will be used to stock her studio with items like picture frames, cameras and photograph papers. She anticipates profits which she will use to expand her business as well as save for her children's education.

In the future she would like to educate her children to the highest level possible.

loans.use: to expand her business and stock her studio.

loans.name: Biliya

texts.en: Biliya remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Biliya, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Biliya  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 16 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs” expressed Biliya   With this loan, Biliya is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Isihaka

texts.en: Isihaka is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Isihaka joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children Adananu, Hajiya, and Amadu. Isihaka is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Isihaka will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products like sand. With access to high quality inputs, Isihaka can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, Isihaka said “I plan to use the money I make this year to provide more food and clothing for my family.” Isihaka is not thinking about just this year, he said: in 5 years, he wants to “ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty.”

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Irmiya

texts.en: Irmiya is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Irmiya joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children. Irmiya is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Irmiya will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would  be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive, but are often diluted with external products like sand. With access to high quality inputs, Irmiya can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14  and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, Irmiya said “I plan to use the money I make this year to expand my farmland”. Irmiya is not thinking about just this year; he said, “in 5 years, I want to become the  most profitable farmer in my community.”

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Abdulhamid

texts.en: Abdulhamid S. is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Abdulhamid S. joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Manniru, Bello,  and  Habibu. Abdulhamid S. is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Abdulhamid S. will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would  be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive, but are often diluted with external products like sand. With access to high quality inputs, Abdulhamid S. can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14  and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, Abdulhamid S. said “I plan to use the money I make this year to provide more food and clothing for my family.” Abdulhamid S. is not thinking about just this year; he said, “in 5 years, I want to become the  most profitable farmer in my community.”

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Damaris

texts.en:
Damaris is 27 years old and married to Geoffrey who adds additional income to support their family. They are planning to have children soon. 
  
Damaris has been running a cosmetics shop along with a boutique business as a secondary investment for one year earning an income of KES 10,000 at the end of every month.

Damaris is now servicing her second loan of KES 45,000 with VisionFund Kenya and intends to use this amount to buy body creams, lotions, braids, wigs, hair weaves and shampoo to sell to her customers on a daily basis.

Damaris plans to use the anticipated income to open another cosmetics and boutique shop in a nearby town and hopes to have a bright future.

loans.use: to buy body creams, lotions, braids, wigs, hair weaves and shampoo to add to her stock.

loans.name: Abdulrazak

texts.en: Abdulrazak is a Babban Gona farmer from Zarto. Abdulrazak is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is this ambition that led Abdulrazak to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Abdulrazak can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Abdulrazak is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season because with this loan, he will finally be able to access the required yield enhancing inputs such as improved seeds. Abdulrazak is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, he will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what changes he would like to make, he said “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family.  Ultimately, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, Abdulrazak will be able to access all the inputs and services to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Emmy

texts.en:
Emmy is 36 years. She is single and supports three people in her family; she has one child who is 12 years. Emmy operates two businesses: a boutique, as well as selling groceries. She has run these businesses for the past 14 years, earning a monthly income of Kshs. 8,000.

Emmy has requested a loan of  Kshs. 30,000, which she will use to purchase clothes to sell. 

With the anticipated profits, she will be able add more stock and pay her child's school fees.

This is Emmy's first loan with VisionFund Kenya. Her hope and dream is to help her dependents in living a comfortable life.

loans.use: to purchase clothes

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 49 years old, married to James, and blessed with one child, age 24 years old. She has been selling various types of utensils for the past four years, and earns a monthly income of KES.30,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES).
	 
She has applied for her second loan of 25,000 KES from VisionFund Kenya, and intends to use the loan amount to buy more quality utensils to sell.                                                                                           

The profit she will use to provide for the family's basic needs, and also pay college fees for the child. She hopes to grow her business and in the future, open a wholesale shop.

loans.use: to buy assorted utensils

She has requested her third loan, which she plans to use to add more items in her grocery stall, like fruit and vegetables (kale, spinach, tomatoes, etc.) She anticipates profits from this stock boost, and she hopes to expand her business.

In the future she would like to be a leading wholesaler in her area.

loans.name: Evangelina

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal VIRGEN INMACULADA CONCEPCION - RIOBAMBA, el banco está ubicado en el distrito de Yanatile, provincia de Calca y departamento de Cusco.

La socia Evangelina  se sigue dedicando al negocio de venta de frutas , la socia lleva a diferentes lugares, la socia vende platanos, naranjas y mandarinas , la socia ya tiene varios años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es tener un local donde pueda vender las frutas . La socia solicita el crédito para comprar naranjas, plátanos y mandarinas . 

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en: The member belongs to the communal bank VIRGEN INMACULADA CONCEPCION - RIOBAMBA. The bank is located in the district of Yanatile, province of Calca and department of Cusco. Evangelina, the member, is still working in the sale of fruits. She brings it to different places. She sells bananas, oranges and mandarins. The member has many years in this business and is doing very well. Her dream is to have a place where she can sell fruits. The member is requesting a loan to buy oranges, bananas and mandarins. The member is happy for the loan and promises to pay the installments of her loan on time.

loans.use: to buy oranges, bananas and mandarins.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose lives in Sindo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay county is located in southwestern Kenya, and borders on Lake Victoria, the second-largest lake in the world. Populations are dense close to the lake, where many individuals make their living from fishing and a few work in the small but slowly growing tourism industry. A popular tourist attraction in Homa Bay county is Ruma National Park, a game reserve that is home to the rare roan antelope, a shy species distantly related to the reticulated giraffe. Most people in Homa Bay make their living from farming, and the rolling hills of the area are dotted with fields and fruit tree plantations.

Rose is a widow with seven children. She runs a small kiosk and she is a farmer as well. She has been farming for 15 years now and she is currently growing maize, beans, amaranth and bananas. Rose is excited about beekeeping as it will earn her some income from the sale of honey and provide her with honey for food.

This is Rose’s first loan with Honey Care and she plans to use the proceeds from her beehives to pay school fees for her children. Rose’s hope for the future is to expand her beekeeping project to enable her to gain financially.

loans.use: To buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth lives in Sindo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay county is located in south-western Kenya, closeto  both the Tanzanian border and Lake Victoria, Africa's largest lake. Despite the proximity to the lake, water infrastructure in Homa Bay remains quite undeveloped, and inconsistent rains and occasional droughts make life difficult for farmers in the area. Nonetheless, farmers have adapted to these challenges, particularly by diversifying their crops to include cassava, sunflowers, sorghum, bananas, groundnuts and millet, as well as drought-resistant varieties of papaya and mangoes. Although beekeeping has not traditionally been practiced in the region, many individuals have expressed interest in keeping bees and are knowledgeable about their pollination benefits.

Elizabeth is married and has four children. Both she and her husband are farmers. They have been farming for seven years now and they are currently growing maize, beans, sorghum and sunflowers. Elizabeth is excited about beekeeping as it will earn her some income from the sale of honey and provide her with honey for food.

This is Elizabeth's first loan with Honey Care and she plans to use the proceeds from her beehives to pay school fees for her children and to start a small business. Elizabeth's hope for the future is to start a small business to expand her income avenues.

loans.use: To buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production

Alice has applied for her second loan of 22,500 KES from VisionFund Kenya and intends to use the loan to buy foodstuff, e.g., wheat flour and sugar, and also to buy more plates, spoons and more firewood for sale. She will use the profit to provide for the family's basic needs. She hopes to grow her business and open a bigger restaurant.

loans.use: to buy foodstuff, e.g., wheat flour and sugar, and also to buy more plates, spoons and more firewood

loans.name: Violet

texts.en:
Violet lives in Sindo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay county is located at the southwestern tip of Kenya, and its northern end is dominated by Lake Victoria, the largest lake in the Southern Hemisphere. Lake Victoria extends into three east African countries, allowing cross-border flows of goods and people. A market day in a lakeside town in Homa Bay county often boasts traders from Uganda, Tanzania and Kenya, all of whom arrive in boats to ply their wares. Although the semi-arid nature of much of Homa Bay county means that poverty rates are quite high, many people in the region hold a strong cultural emphasis on education, and as a result, school attendance figures around Homa Bay are above the national average.

Violet is married and has three children. She runs a bakery. Both she and her husband are farmers. They have been farming for five years now and they are currently growing maize, beans, mangoes, watermelon, bananas, avocados, sunflower and trees in their farm. Violet is excited about beekeeping, as it will provide her with honey for food and the bees will aid in pollinating their crops.

This is violet's first loan with Honey Care and she plans to use the proceeds from her beehives to expand her baking business. Violet's hope for the future is to help her community access beehives to do beekeeping and to increase her honey production for more income.

loans.use: To buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph lives in Sindo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay county is located in southwestern Kenya, close both the Tanzanian border and Lake Victoria, Africa's largest lake. Despite the proximity to the lake, water infrastructure in Homa Bay remains quite undeveloped, and inconsistent rains and occasional droughts make life difficult for farmers in the area. Nonetheless, farmers have adapted to these challenges, particularly by diversifying their crops to include cassava, sunflower, sorghum, bananas, groundnuts and millet, as well as drought-resistant varieties of papaya and mangoes. Although beekeeping has not traditionally been practiced in the region, many individuals have expressed interest in keeping bees and are knowledgeable about their pollination benefits.

Joseph is married and has three children. Both he and his wife run a small business of selling pastries. They also practice farming. They have been farming for four years now and they are currently growing maize, beans, green grams and groundnuts. loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph lives in Sindo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay county is located in southwestern Kenya, close both the Tanzanian border and Lake Victoria, Africa's largest lake. Despite the proximity to the lake, water infrastructure in Homa Bay remains quite undeveloped, and inconsistent rains and occasional droughts make life difficult for farmers in the area. Nonetheless, farmers have adapted to these challenges, particularly by diversifying their crops to include cassava, sunflower, sorghum, bananas, groundnuts and millet, as well as drought-resistant varieties of papaya and mangoes. Although beekeeping has not traditionally been practiced in the region, many individuals have expressed interest in keeping bees and are knowledgeable about their pollination benefits.

Joseph is married and has five children. He runs a small mobile phone business. He also practices farming with his wife. They have been farming for six years now and they are currently growing maize, beans, bananas, mangoes, citrus fruits and sunflower. Joseph is excited about beekeeping as it will earn him some income from the sale of honey and it will also enable him to conserve the environment by planting more trees.

This is Joseph’s first loan with Honey Care and he plans to use the proceeds from his beehives to pay school fees for his children. Joseph’s hope for the future is to expand his beekeeping project, have his children educated and improve his life.

loans.use: To buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice lives in Sindo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay county is located at the southwestern tip of Kenya, and its northern end is dominated by Lake Victoria, the largest lake in the Southern Hemisphere. Lake Victoria extends into three east African countries, allowing cross-border flows of goods and people. A market day in a lakeside town in Homa Bay county often boasts traders from Uganda, Tanzania and Kenya, all of whom arrive in boats to ply their wares. Although the semi-arid nature of much of Homa Bay county means that poverty rates are quite high, many people in the region hold a strong cultural emphasis on education, and as a result school attendance figures around Homa Bay are above the national average.

Beatrice is married and has three children. Both she and her husband are farmers. They have been farming for six years now and they are currently growing maize, beans, millet, vegetables and sunflower in their farm. Beatrice is excited about beekeeping as it will earn her some income from the sale of honey, provide her with honey for medicine and it will encourage her to plant trees for flowers.

This is Beatrice’s first loan with Honey Care and she plans to use the proceeds from her beehives to pay school fees for her children and repair her house. Beatrice’s hope for the future is to have a healthy family and good housing and to have her children educated.

loans.use: To buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Barack

texts.en:
Barack lives in Sindo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay county is located in southwestern Kenya and borders on Lake Victoria, the second-largest lake in the world. Populations are dense close to the lake, where many individuals make their living from fishing, and a few work in the small but slowly growing tourism industry. A popular tourist attraction in Homa Bay county is Ruma National Park, a game reserve that is home to the rare roan antelope, a shy species distantly related to the reticulated giraffe. Most people in Homa Bay make their living from farming, and the rolling hills of the area are dotted with fields and fruit tree plantations.

Barack is a widower with five children. He is a retiree and he is currently a farmer. He has been farming for five years now and he is currently growing maize, sorghum, beans, green grams, ground nuts and sunflower. Barack is excited about beekeeping as it will earn him some income from the sale of honey.

This is Barack’s first loan with Honey Care and he plans to use the proceeds from his beehives to pay school fees for his children. Barack’s hope for the future is to improve his housing.

loans.use: To buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en:
HELLO LENDERS! Meet Miriam a very hardworking, honest and easy to get along with mother who is 60 years of age. She hails from Eldoret area of Kenya which is home to the elite and best athletes that the world has ever produced.  The Eldoret area is also an educational town and is home to Moi University. Miriam is a mother of four lovely and adorable children that she really cherishes and will do anything in her power to fully provide for. Miriam has been farming for the past seven years and through all these years she has been making tremendous strides in profits. Miriam's primary source of income is milk selling, egg selling and crop farming and through this she has managed to earn a decent and honest income.

Miriam loves nature so much she has planted trees on her farm and also she has so much space to practice dairy farming, but one challenge she is facing as a woman is being able to access funds so that she can buy a dairy cow.  Miriam is planning to start selling milk to her neighbors and around the market, but the main challenge she is facing is getting her business off the ground.  That is why she is kindly requesting a loan to buy a dairy cow. Through the loan Miriam will be able to acquire more income and she will be able to secure her children's future and also improve her living conditions.

Miriam tracks her income and finances and she is very strict with unnecessary spending and she believes because of these qualities she will be able to save more and assure her children and grandchildren of a secure future. Miriam's plan is not only to sell her milk to the nearby market, but to be able to sell to other markets and hence increase her income and improve her living standards.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Dauda

texts.en: Dauda is a 45-year-old farmer from Kargo.  As a Babban Gona member, Dauda is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Dauda can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. Like all Babban Gona members, Dauda is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of up to 30 bags of maize per hectare, double the national average.  Dauda is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children: Musa and  Mikah. Dauda’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to make more money for myself and my family”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Elvira Del Socorro

texts.es:
Las venta de joyas de plata y de cosméticos, no fueron suficientes para Elvira, una joven de 37 años, casada y madre de un hijo de siete años, al cual sueña con verlo graduado de la universidad. Elvira, siempre pensando en la educación de su bebe, decidió sin pensarlo lanzarse a otro barco, pues estableció su propio cafetín, con el cual ya lleva un año. La visión de esta mujer no fue en ningún momento opacada por no haber llegado a la universidad, al contrario la llenó de fuerzas para que su hijo si tenga la oportunidad de hacerlo. 
Elvira inició con el ahorro de sus otras ventas de plata y cosméticos en su casa, lo que le ha permitido mantenerse un poco con el apoyo de su esposo. De vez en cuando vende comida por encargo, pero muchos llegan a comer a su establecimiento, por lo que necesita de un préstamo para comprar mesas, sillas, comida, vasos, platos y otros productos que le permitirán ofrecer un mejor servicio, pues la producción de comida será mayor y el local deberá tener las mejores condiciones. Entre sus planes está seguir creciendo con su negocio y mejorar su vivienda.
texts.en:
Elvira is a 37-year old married woman who has a 7-year old son. Her dream is to see him graduating from college so, after realizing selling silver jewelry and cosmetics was not profitable enough, she decided to start her own small café one year ago. Her view was never limited by the fact that she never attended university and actually that gave her the strength to fight for her son to have the opportunity. 

Elvira started off with the savings she had from her previous business of silver and cosmetics, as well as with the support of her husband. Sometimes she also sells food by the order, but a lot of people arrive to her café to eat. This is why she needs a loan to buy tables, chairs, food, glasses, plates and other products that will help her to provide a better service now that a larger food production and a better prepared space will be needed.

Her goal is to keep growing her business and to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: to buy tables, chairs, food, glasses, plates and other products.

loans.name: Matta

texts.en: Matta is a 50-year-old farmer from Dantani.  As a Babban Gona member, Matta is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Matta can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Matta is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, she will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Matta is hopeful about what the future holds; she  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, she will finally be able to afford to educate her children; Shitu,  and  Zakaria. Matta’s dreams do not end here: “ultimately, I want to make more money for myself and my family”, she expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.en: Gabriel remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Gabriel, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Gabriel  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family” expressed Gabriel.   With this loan, Gabriel is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Yohanna Salau

texts.en: Yohanna Salau remembers not being able to pay school fees during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona member. Now, Yohanna Salau, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Yohanna Salau is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  Yohanna Salau expressed that “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, expressed Yohanna. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Hilda

texts.es:
Hilda es de la ciudad de Carapeguá, está estudiando la carrera de administración, y comenta que siempre se propone metas, y que su ideal es siempre poder capacitarse y tener una estabilidad, laboral y económica.
Ella pide este préstamo para poder pagar las cuotas de su universidad, ya que asi podrá seguir luchando por sus metas como lo viene haciendo.
texts.en:
Hilda is originally from Carapeguá and is studying a degree in Administration. She says she always set herself goals and that her dream is to become a professional and to enjoy work and financial stability. 

She is requesting this loan to pay for tuition, so that she can keep fighting for her goals.

loans.use: to pay for university tuition.

loans.name: Fidel

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al banco comunal VIRGEN INMACULADA CONCEPCION - RIOBAMBA, el banco está ubicado en el distrito de Yanatile, provincia de Calca y departamento de Cusco.

El socio Fidel se dedica al negocio de cultivo de frutas, el socio tiene un terreno donde cultiva platanos,cafe,mandarinas y naranjas, el socio trabaja desde las 6:00 a.m hasta las 5:00 p.m,el socio ya tiene varios años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño del socio es ampliar su terreno de cultivo. El socio solicita el crédito para comprar semillas y fertilizantes.



El socio está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en: Fidel belongs to the "VIRGEN INMACULADA CONCEPCION - RIOBAMBA" communal bank, which is located in Yanatile district, Calca province, in the Department of Cusco. Fidel works growing fruit. He has a plot of land where he grows bananas, coffee, mandarins and oranges. He works from 6 am until 5 pm. He has been in the business for a number of year and things are going well for him. His dream is to expand his land under cultivation. He is requesting the loan to buy seeds and fertilizer. He is happy with the loan and promises to comply with the payment of his installments.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Gema Del Carmen

texts.es:
La gente ve pasar por los pasillos del mercado oriental, cada quince minutos, las carretillas que alquila Gema, carretillas que junto con su esposo, quien trabaja como soldador, elaboran con sus propias manos desde hace tres años. Gema tiene 30 años y tiene tres hijos de las edades de 14, 9 y 4 años, quienes son muy responsables en su educación, pues su mamá siempre les ha aconsejado salir adelante, ya que ella solo llego a tercer año de secundaria.
Gema inició a los 27 años con el negocio que antes era de su suegro y así, junto con el apoyo del padre de su esposo, han continuado. Ella siempre ha sido creativa a la hora de elaborar una carretilla, pues se ajusta a sus necesidades. Sin embargo, quiere llegar a más público, extenderse a otros mercados, por lo que necesita de un préstamo para comprar material como hierro, llantas y soldaduras para aumentar la cantidad de carretillas para alquilar. Esta sería una gran oportunidad para ella, pues sus clientes aumentaran y podrá ahorrar para comprar su propia casa.
texts.en:
Every 15 minutes, a wheelbarrow rented from Gema is seen in the oriental market. She and her husband, who works as a welder, have been making them with their own hands for 3 years. Gema is 30 years old and has 3 children, ages 14, 9 and 4, who are very responsible in their studies. Their mother only studied until third grade and has always advised them to get ahead. 

Gema started the business when she was 27 years old. It used to be run by her father-in-law and, thanks to his support, she was able to continue with it. She has always been creative in building the wheelbarrows and looks to meet the needs in each case. However, she wants to reach more people and expand to other markets, which is why she is requesting a loan to buy materials, such as iron, tires and welding, to increase production. This would be a great opportunity for her because the number of clients would increase and she would be able to save and buy her own house.

loans.use: to buy materials, such as iron, tires and welding.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Vicenta

texts.es:
La Sra. Vicenta tiene 55 años, esta casada con el Sr. Antonio de 58 años, sus hijos ya son mayores de edad y en su mayoria profesionales independientes, que con gran esfuerzo y sacrificio pudieron criar.
Anteriormente trabajaban de empleados en distintos lugares, pero con los años y con los ahorros pudieron montar en su casa una despensa, con la que pudieron mantener a su familia.
Vicenta pide este préstamo para poder invertirlo en la compra de leche, huevo, panificados, aceites, lácteos, bebidas etc., lo que le permitirá seguir con sus ventas y mejorar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Vicenta is 55 years old and is married to Antonio who is 58 years old. Their children are adults and for the most part independent professionals. She raised them with great effort and sacrifice.

Previously the two of them worked in different places, but over the years and with their savings they were able to establish a grocery store running out of their home, with which she could support their family.

Vicenta asks for this this loan to invest in the purchase of milk, eggs, bread, oils, dairy, drinks etc., which will allow her to continue with her sales and improve her income.

loans.use: buy milk, eggs, breads, oils, dairy, drinks etc..

loans.name: Yahaira Magaly

texts.es:
La venta de cosméticos era la fuente de ingresos para Yahaira y su familia, además del trabajo de su esposo, sin embargo, no sentía que fuera su trabajo, pues quería algo más propio que ayudará a pagar los gastos de la casa y la educación de sus hijos que ahora tienen 5 y 9 años. Poco a poco fue ahorrando, hasta conseguir lo necesario para establecer su propia pulpería. Ahora, a sus 29 años, ya tiene su propio negocio grande con un poco más de un año desde que lo abrió.
Afortunadamente Yahaira siempre ha tenido el apoyo de su familia completa, por lo que la sigue motivando a querer progresar. Ahora necesita de un préstamo para comprar granos básicos, gaseosas, aceite, huevos, entre otros productos que vende a diario, esto le ayudará a tener suficiente en su pulpería y que sus clientes se sientan satisfechos de visitarla. En un futuro piensa mejorar la infraestructura de un negocio y su casa ¿y por qué no comprar un automóvil? Todo es válido cuando se ha trabajado fuerte, por esta razón, ayuda a Yahaira a cumplir con sus sueños y a que sus hijos no les falte para ir a la escuela.
texts.en:
Yahaira used to sell cosmetics, which was the main income source for her family together with her husband's job. However, she did not feel committed to the job and wanted to work on something of her own to cover household expenses and the education of her children, who are 5 and 9 years old. She saved little by little until she had enough money to start her own grocery store. She is now 29 years old and has had her own business for over a year. 

Fortunately, Yahaira has always had the support of her family, who still motivates her to improve. She now needs a loan to buy basic grains, sodas, oil, eggs and other products that she sells every day. This will allow her to stock her store and provide a good service to her customers. In the future she plans to make improvements to the store and her house, as well as to buy a car. Everything is possible when you have worked hard. For this reason, please support Yahaira so that she can reach her dreams and provide her children with a good education.

loans.use: to buy basic grains, sodas, oil, eggs and other products.

loans.name: Los Comerciantes De Virgen Asunta Group

texts.es:
Nuestros socios pertenecen al banco comunal “LOS COMERCIANTES DE VIRGEN ASUNTA” situado en la ciudad del Cusco, en el distrito de Iscuchaka, provincia de Anta departamento del Cusco. 


La socia es la Sra. Rita ella es soltera y tiene 52 años y tiene 4 hijos; La socia trabaja en su negocio de tienda de abarrotes, la socia vende productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar, leche y aceite, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 10:00 p.m, la socia ya tiene 5 años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de tienda de abarrotes. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar leche, azúcar, aceite y arroz.



Los otros socios se dedican al negocio de venta de chocolates, negocio de venta de celulares, negocio de tienda de abarrotes y negocio de restaurant.



La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
These members belong to the “LOS COMERCIANTES DE VIRGEN ASUNTA” communal bank, located in the city of Cusco, in Iscuchaka District, Anta Province, Cusco Department.

Rita is 52 years old, single and has 4 children. She works in her business, a grocery store. She sells basic food items like rice, sugar, milk and oil. She works from 8 am until 10 pm. She has run this business for 5 years and things are going well for her. Her dream is to expand her grocery store. She is requesting the loan to milk, sugar, oil and rice.

The other members work selling chocolates, a cell phone business, a grocery store and a restaurant business.

The member thanks all those who form part of this dream through this loan and promises to pay her installments on time.

loans.use: to buy milk. sugar, oil and rice.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul sells plastic wares in his shop. He has been doing this business for the last five years and gets a monthly income of 15,000 KES. He is 36 years old, married, and blessed with two children. 

He has applied for his first loan from us as he needs capital to add more wares. He was introduced to VisionFund Kenya by one of our credit officers while marketing.

In the future, Paul would like to have a stable business.

loans.use: to add more plastics for resale

loans.name: Nellya

texts.ru: Нелля, 54 года, не замужем, есть взрослый сын. Нелля в качестве основного дохода занимается предоставлением маникюрных и педикюрных услуг в салоне красоты. Данным видом деятельности она занимается на протяжении 19 лет, уже наработала постоянную клиентуру и хочет расширить свою деятельность. Ее ежемесячный доход составляет в среднем 20,000 сом (KGS). Нелля обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 30,000 сом (KGS) на покупку оборудования для работы, а именно педикюрного кресла. Доходы от кредита Нелля планирует вложить в дальнейшее развитие своей деятельности, она хочет сделать ремонт в своем доме и , конечно же, мечтает открыть свой собственный салон красоты, так как имеет большой опыт и знания в данной сфере деятельности.
texts.en:
Nellya is 54 and unmarried, with an adult son. She earns a living giving manicures and pedicures in a beauty salon. She has worked in this occupation for 19 years and has a regular clientele and wants to expand her operations. Her monthly income is about 20,000 KGS. 

Nellya has turned to Bai Tushum Bank for a loan of 30,000 KGS to purchase tools for her work, specifically a pedicure chair. She plans to put profits from the loan into further development of her business and into home renovations and, of course, dreams of opening her own salon, since she has a lot of experience and knowledge in this field.

loans.use: to buy a pedicure chair to be more competitive and increase her number of clients

loans.name: Shafiu

texts.en: Shafiu remembers the extreme poverty that his family faced during a particularly bad harvest. This is before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, as a Babban Gona member, Shafiu, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Shafiu, is ambitious and is aiming to reap 50 per hectare this season. Shafiu expressed that “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, Shafiu is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en: Mohammad is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Mohammad joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Garba and Naziru. Mohammad is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, he will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, Mohammad, would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products like sand. With access to high quality inputs through this Babban Gona loan, Mohammad can reap 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14  and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, Mohammad said “I plan to use the money I make this year to provide more food and clothing for my family. However, Mohammad is not thinking about just this year; he said, “In 5 years, I want to Make more money for myself and my family.”

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Usman

texts.en: Usman remembers the extreme poverty that his family faced during a particularly bad harvest. This is before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, as a Babban Gona member, Usman, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14. However, Usman, is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 per hectare this season.  Usman expressed that “In 5 years, I want to ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty.” With this loan, Usman is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Milka

texts.en:
Hello, lenders! Meet Milka, who is a 27-year-old woman. She is very hardworking, young and very ambitious. She hails from Nyamira area in Kenya, an area known to have the best soils and weather patterns that favor farming. She is a proud mother of three children and has been doing farming for the past 12 years. Milka never got the chance to go to college because she lacked the money to pay the tuition. But she kept her dream on track and, through farming, has been able to earn a decent income. Milka's dream is to see her children get a good education and have a good future, and she will do anything in her power to make sure that happens.

Milka practices mixed farming. She wants to increase her income, so she is seeking a loan to buy poultry. Through poultry farming, Milka is sure that her living conditions will be improved and that she will have a bright future. Women like Milka have a problem accessing financial resources. Through Juhudi Kilimo and Kiva lenders, she is sure of a bright future and making her dreams come true.

Milka has gone through the repayment schedule, and she is comfortable repaying the loan from the increased profits she will be earning.

loans.use: To buy poultry

loans.name: Watidgeswende Group

texts.fr:
Mme G.PAULINE est responsable du groupe WATIDGESWENDE. Mariée, elle est mère de 09enfants. Le plus âgé a 34 ans  et le moins âgé a  12ans   . 04 vont à l’école et elle a 05personnes en charge.
Mme fait le tissage depuis  30ans. Elle s’approvisionne dans les marchés en ville.
Elle veut s’acheter 01balle de fil à tisser, 01kg de teinture et 02paquets de fil brillant.
Mme veut ouvrir un compte d’épargne pour ses bénéfices et ambitionne diversifier son activité en ajoutant  le commerce du charbon de bois.
texts.en: Ms. G. Pauline is the representative of Watidgeswende Group.  She is married and mother of nine children; the oldest is 34-years old and the youngest is 12-years old.  Four attend school and she has five dependents.  Ms. G. Pauline has been weaving for 30 years.  She buys supplies at the markets in the city.  She wants to buy 1 ball of yarn, 1 kg of dye, and 2 packets of shiny thread. She wants to open a savings account for her profits and she plans to diversify her business by also selling charcoal.

loans.use: to buy 1 ball of yarn, 1 kg of dye, and 2 packets of shiny thread.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for a post graduate course in dentistry.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a 40 year old married man and a father to two children ages 13 and 5 years.  He runs a barber shop and also rears cattle as a secondary business. Peter is able to make a monthly profit of 22,000 Kenya shillings per month.

Peter has applied for a forth loan to add more shaving machines for his barber shop. He hopes to boost his income and increase the number of clients tht come to his shop..

In future he would like to be a successful businessman.

loans.use: to purchase more shaving machines.

loans.name: Josefa

texts.es:
Un sin número de personas emigran de un lugar a otro, en su mayoría buscando una mejor oportunidad laboral. Josefa, tiene 50 años, es madre soltera de seis hijos entre las edades de 34 a 22, los cuales son todos independientes y apoyan a Josefa en todo momento, y es una de esas personas que se mueven de su pueblo para buscar una mejor vida. Ella solo estudio hasta secundaria debido a problemas económicos, sin embargo eso no la detuvo en emprender con su propio negocio, el cual es caracterizado por 23 años con su variedad de productos. 
Afortunadamente siempre ha tenido el apoyo económico de su esposo y de una de sus hijas, lo que la ha impulsado a seguir creciendo. Ahora quiere seguir esa ruta hasta llega a ser autosuficiente, por lo que necesita de un préstamo para comprar más cosméticos, perfumes, cremas y más productos que tanto exigen sus clientes al llegar al negocio. Esto le servirá para aumentar su inventario y ofrecer un mejor servicio. Entre sus planes está mejorar su vivienda, por lo que sabe que con el esfuerzo, dedicación y con el apoyo de todos podrá cumplirlo.
texts.en:
There are countless people who move from one place to another, mostly seeking work opportunities.  Josefa, 50, is a single mother of 6 children between the ages of 34 and 22.  All of her children are independent and are supporting Josefa at this time.  She is one of these people who moved from her town to find a better life.  

Josefa has only a secondary education, due to financial problems.  However, this has not stopped her from starting up her own business.  For 23 years, she has had a business selling a variety of products.

Fortunately, she has always had the financial support of her husband and one of her daughters, and this has helped her to continue to grow the business.  Now she wants to continue to follow this route toward becoming self-sufficient.  To do this, she needs a loan to buy more cosmetics, perfumes, creams, and other products that the customers who come to her business are demanding.  This will enable her to increase her inventory and offer better service.  One of her plans for the future is improving her house, and she knows that with effort, dedication, and everyone's support she will be able to do it.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics, perfumes, and creams

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is a 34 year old lady whose is married to Peter.  Together they are blessed with two children ages 17 and 11 year. She runs a clothes boutique and this has been her business for the last 12 years.  She earns a good monthly profit.

Ruth has applied for her sixth loan with Visionfund, and she plans to add new products like dresses, trousers and shirts, to cater for her ever changing clientele. 

She anticipates profits from this business boost and plans to use this income to expand her business and  pay school fees for her children.

In future Ruth would like to be a landlord and manage rental houses.

loans.use: to add new products to her boutique.

loans.name: Sithokozile

texts.en:
Aged 28 years, Sithokozile is a businesswoman who lives in the Lupane district of Zimbabwe.  She operates a stall at the local flea market, where she sells clothes and stationery. She also assists orphans with their household chores. 

With the loan she is requesting from Kiva, she would like to purchase more clothes and stationery to sell so she can increase sales and profits. With the increased profits, she would like to expand her business and create employment for the people of her community.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and stationery to sell.

loans.name: Kol

texts.en:
This is Kol, a 53-year-old married villager man and a father of two, both in their early 20's.

Kol works as a night man, and at the same time he’s got his little store where he sells haberdasheries; his wife is talented at handmade crafts such as crochet, embroidery, etc, and she sells them for money; thus, both of them make an income, enough for the daily expenses and to put a bit on the side for the rainy days also. 

They now want to add more items to their store, since the wife deals with lots of young women to whom she sells her crafts; they always ask for special items needed for their wedding or dowry.  They live in a little town, just north of Lezha city, that is visited by foreigners and domestic and foreign tourists due to the city's heritage.

loans.use: to add more items such as wedding decorations that are in demand in their region due to their customs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a printer for her work

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more chicks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more hair extensions and salon equipment.

loans.name: Ntombizodwa

texts.en:
Ntombizodwa is a 20-year-old businesswoman who is single and living in the Lupane district of Zimbabwe. She has a poultry rearing project where she produces broiler chickens in batches of 50 every six weeks. Ntombizodwa inspires young women, as she is a hard worker and a CAMA (Camfed’s alumnae network) member who volunteers by assisting the elderly with their fieldwork. She has been successfully running her business for eight months, with occasionally getting help from her young sister. 

Ntombizodwa would like to use this loan to expand her business by increasing the number of broilers. This would increase the business’ profitability and enable her to provide for the needy children in her community, and to further her education.

loans.use: To purchase more chicks.

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en:
As a Camfed Learner Guide in the Wedza district of Zimbabwe, Belinda volunteers her time to teaching life skills to young students. She also assists elders in her community, and operates a stall at a local flea market where she sells various clothing items and accessories. 

Due to the success of her small business and the demand of her customers, Belinda intends to use a Kiva loan to increase her stock. She will purchase shoes, slippers, shirts, t-shirts, trousers, skirts, baby clothes, and jewelry in bulk; one day, Belinda will open her own store. If her business grows, Belinda can continue to support her family.

loans.use: To purchase shoes, slippers, shirts, t-shirts, trousers, skirts, baby clothes, and jewelry in bulk

loans.name: Ambatiessiri 1 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe AMBATIESSIRI 1est constitué de femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans et 3 enfants. La plupart d’entre eux vivent dans des familles polygamiques à Dioni un des villages de la préfecture de Baroueli, Région de Ségou, (quatrième région administrative de la République du Mali).
Les femmes du groupe AMBATIESSIRI 1collaborent avec Soro Yiriwaso à fin de mieux organisé leurs activités hivernales. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres (mil, arachide, sésame, haricot etc.) 
Elles sont à leur septième collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce prêt, Madame  MAMAN, première personne de la droite vers la gauche dans le rang des debout, compte payer ses frais de labour, de sarclage, acheter de la semence, de l’engrais, de l’herbicide et autre petit équipement pour entretenir son champ d’environ 0,5 hectare de sésame.
A la fin de la campagne, les productions sont vendues en espèce à Konobougou.
Elle envisage réalise un bénéfice moyen de 80 000F CFA par campagne qui sera en parti investi dans le commerce.
